Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: CEDAR--Large-Scale Characterization of the Sub-Auroral Polarization Stream and Its Impacts on the Ionosphere-Thermosphere System
Award.AbstractNarration: During geomagnetic storms the region of the ionosphere that lies just equatorward of the auroral zone is often perturbed by a longitudinally-extended channel of high-speed (>1 km/s) plasma flow known as the sub-auroral polarization stream (SAPS). The investigators will analyze observations of ionospheric disturbances through the current period of solar cycle maximum with the aim of deriving a comprehensive, observationally based model of SAPS. The study will examine the onset, spread, and decay of SAPS flows and chart the accompanying changes observed in total electron content (TEC). Coordinated experiments will be conducted with the recently refurbished Incoherent Scatter Radar (ISR) at Millstone Hill in order to relate the SAPS electric field dynamics to changes in ionospheric density and chemistry and to gauge their effects on the neutral atmosphere. The SAPS phenomenon is associated with strong poleward-directed electric fields (>50 mV/m) and a deep depression, or trough, in ionospheric densities. SAPS is believed to be a consequence of a feedback process whereby magnetic field-aligned current of magnetospheric origin closes across the ionospheric trough, eliciting chemical changes that further reduce the ionospheric density while increasing the electric field in a manner that maintains current continuity. The SAPS phenomenon has important consequences for structuring ionospheric plasma, ionospheric composition, formation of plasma irregularities, and coupling to the neutral atmosphere. The attainment of a comprehensive, observationally-based understanding of SAPS and its impacts on the thermosphere would be a major advance. SAPS has traditionally been studied with single radars and satellites, leading to characterizations that are limited in their utility for understanding the evolution and impacts of SAPS as a multi-dimensional, global-scale phenomenon. Recent advances in observational techniques have fundamentally altered the research landscape. The construction of a mid-latitude chain of SuperDARN radars in North America has made possible simultaneous (~1 min) views of SAPS plasma flows and electric fields across many hours of MLT while the expansion of the network of Global Positioning System (GPS) receivers has made possible continental-scale mapping of TEC on similar time scales. Initial comparisons indicate that the SAPS observed by the radars are seated in an enhanced trough-like density feature that is mapped by TEC. This work will lead to the development of a phenomenological model of SAPS that is suitable for testing theoretical ideas and the development of storm-time ionospheric models, the dissemination of global-scale information on recent SAPS events to the wider community, the increased application of the GPS TEC database to scientific research, and the instruction of scientists on the use of these data. In addition, a graduate student at Virginia Tech will be trained in the new experimental techniques and in the merging of data from the SuperDARN radars, GPS, and incoherent scatter radar.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The environment of Earth in space is sometimes perturbed by major disturbances known as geomagnetic storms. These are caused by explosive outbursts of magnetized plasma from the sun that collide with the outer boundary of the volume carved out of the solar wind by Earth’s magnetic field, which is known as the magnetosphere. There are a range of harmful impacts on technological systems such as electrical power grids, radio communications, and satellite navigation and also dangers to humans at high altitudes especially at high latitudes. The science of space weather aims to understand, model, and predict the disturbances and their effects. Several decades of observations with single satellites and radars have demonstrated that one dramatic manifestation of space weather disturbance in the ionosphere is the SubAuroral Polarization Stream (SAPS). At altitudes of several hundred kilometers the plasma of the ionosphere flows at very high speeds (~ km/s) during SAPS events within latitudinally narrow channels near the poleward edge of the geomagnetic mid-latitude region, or just equatorward of the high-latitude region where auroral effects and disturbances are prominent. It has become clear that SAPS are a defining feature of the coupled magnetosphere-ionosphere-thermosphere (M-I-T) system whereby electric currents flow vertically along geomagnetic field lines from the nightside inner magnetosphere and close by horizontal flow in the ionosphere across regions of reduced ionization density and conductivity. As such, a full characterization of SAPS would be an important step towards understanding M-I-T coupling and space weather.

In this study we have conducted a comprehensive analysis of SAPS observed with a mid-latitude chain of HF radars that are located along an arc that extends from Virginia through Kansas and Oregon to the Aleutian Islands (Alaska). This is the U. S. mid-latitude component of the Super Dual Auroral Radar Network (SuperDARN) and it provides an unprecedented combination of coverage and temporal resolution for imaging SAPS channels. Coordinated observations have been carried out with a specialized radar within the field of view of the HF radars that provides complementary measurements of plasma parameters. A statistical model of the occurrence of SAPS has been derived that demonstrates the surprising result that SAPS channels are observed even under relatively quiet, and certainly non-storm, conditions. This indicates that the mechanism underlying SAPS is more generally active and even more fundamental to our understanding of the coupled M-I-T system. The quiet-time SAPS channel are distinguished from their storm-time counterparts by lower rates of occurrence, much lower plasma velocities (reaching at least as low as 100 m/s), and higher latitudes of occurrence. The attached figure depicts the occurrence probability of SAPS flows over a geomagnetic latitude - Magnetic Local Time (MLT) grid as a function of disturbance level indicated by the Dst index where Dst < - 40 nT and more negative is associated with stormier conditions. The occurrence of SAPS has been compared with the distribution of Total Electron Content (TEC)  derived from GPS satellite measurements to show that SAPS are constrained by the boundaries of the mid-latitude trough in ionization density and to demonstrate that SAPS and trough dynamics are closely linked. The defining characteristics of SAPS in terms of occurrence and velocity have been encapsulated into empirical models that provide a basis for predicting SAPS and for testing comprehensive first-principles models of space weather.

The work of this project has contributed to the training of four PhD-level graduate students and a postdoctoral fellow. The basis for this research was established by the construction of the mid-latitude chain of SuperDARN HF radars across the U.S. under the NSF Mid-Sized Infrastructure (MSI) program.
